content.description:
Another great but short climb.  There's a bomber rock up top to set up your own top rope anchor off of.  There's plans to bolt it, but for now its a build your own anchor type of climb.  The crux is right at the start up a crack leading half way up.  It takes a bit of commitment and a good crimp hold to get past it.  There's a cheater route to looker's left of the climb that's much easier but takes you way off center so be careful of the swing if you fall there.  In August, blueberries grow on the top and they make a great reward after a challenging technical climb.



If you go to the lookout at the parking area near the town depot you'll see 2 large rock stacks below in the gorge. This climb is on the stack to the right.  It's on the East side of that stack farthest away from the river.  There's an easy scramble to the top to set up your anchor.

Build your own top rope anchor

On the arrett face to the right of the overhanging face there's a great 5.10 route. It starts with a short overhang with gook jug holds, then as you pass the first 10ft up, you go more vertical and the holds transition to good pinch holds.

It's a short but challenging climb with easy access and a great view of the river.



Under the lookout a couple hundred feet down the trail that starts by the town Depot in the upper Gorge Parking area there's a cool overhanging face.  To the right of the lookout there's a steep trail down to the bottom for you to walk after setting up your Top Rope anchor above.  Just over the railing of the lookout is a short decent to a single bolt.  Below that there's 2 additional bolts to set up a Top Rope anchor.

The climb beta is best to the left (looking out from above) of the overhang.  But the overhang has possible ways up too for more skilled climbers.


There's a single Bolt to clip for protection while setting up the anchor on the 2 bolts closer to the edge of the overhang.

There's two (or maybe more) ways up.  To the right side of the wall there's a clean face that's about a 5.8 difficulty called "Hip's Don't Lie" as there's some moves that are fun to test your flexability.  To the left of that line there's an easier 5.6 cheater route for beginners called "Hip's Do Lie".



Next to "The Geoffrey" climb towards the Platform for Zipline number 5 On the Exploits Zip operation.  You can reach the top from the path above.

2 Bolts ready for Top Rope Anchor.

Super accessible and sunny route overlooking the Exploits River canyon.  This sport route uses 5 quickdraws plus 2 for the anchor at the top. It's a great beginner route for people learning to sport climb or anyone wanting to just practice in a safe spot.  The face has plenty of options to discover new betas if you choose to top rope it instead.

There's a couple large and beautiful rose bushes below hence the naming theme on this rock.



This route is right over the railing by the lookout next to the parking lot in the upper gorge/canyon park area near the town Parks and Rec depot.  To the right of the lookout is a pathway the fishermen use to get to the river below.  Take that path down and then hook left under the lookout to find the first bolts to the route.  

Careful not to snag yourself on the rose bushes below.  They're easy enough to avoid, but be warned just the same.

There are bolts and hangers up the route with a pair at the top to anchor for Top rope if desired

Along the Gorge Park trail system in Grand Falls - Windsor there are several lookouts overlooking the Exploits River. Under those lookouts are a variety of short climbs ranging from simple scrambles to more technical climbs. "Rose Clipin's", "Hip's Don't Lie" and "The Geoffrey" climbs have top rope bolts placed but as of this post, you'll need to bring your own gear to set up an anchor of your own on the rocks and trees above the "Blueberry" climb.
